name: monodon-monoceros
definition: The narwhal is a medium-sized toothed whale that possesses a large tusk from a protruding canine tooth.
description:
Narwhal is one of two living species of whale in the family Monodontidae, along with the beluga whale.

Like the beluga, narwhals are medium-sized whales.

The narwhal males are distinguished by a long, straight, helical tusk, which is an elongated upper left canine.

For both sexes, excluding the male's tusk, the total body size can range from 3.95 to 5.5 meters; the males are slightly larger than the females.

The average weight of an adult narwhal is 800 to 1,600 kilograms.

Narwhals do not have a dorsal fin, and their neck vertebrae are jointed like those of most other mammals, not fused as in dolphins and most whales.

Narwhals can live up to 50 years.

In the winter, the male narwhals occasionally dive up to 1,500 m in depth, with dives lasting up to 25 minutes.

The narwhal is scattered throughout Arctic waters and the North Atlantic Ocean.

Most of them are found in Greenland and the eastern part of the Canadian Arctic Ocean.

They forage at any depth, not going far from the pack ice in the Arctic Ocean.

In winter, it feeds on benthic prey, mostly flatfish, under dense pack ice.

During the summer, narwhals eat mostly Arctic cod and Greenland halibut, with other fish such as polar cod making up the remainder of their diet.

They are often killed by suffocation after being trapped due to the formation of sea ice.

Other causes of death, specifically among young whales, are starvation and predation by killer whales.

Narwhals are polygynous, an adult male mating with multiple females during one mating season.

Mating usually occurs from March to May, when males court the females and compete with one another.

The gestation period is around 15 months, with calves being born in July and August the year following.

Narwhals give birth to a single calf and they are born tail first.

The tusks of males do not grow until they are weaned, when they are about one year old.

Young narwhals can swim soon after birth.

A female will give birth once every three years.

Males generally are sexually mature between the ages of 8 to 10, while females achieve maturity between 4 and 7 years.

Narwhals, like most toothed whales, communicate with clicks, whistles, and knocks.

Each year, they migrate from bays into the ocean as summer comes.

Found primarily in Canadian Arctic and Greenlandic and Russian waters, the narwhal is a uniquely specialized Arctic predator.

Estimates of the world narwhal population are around 130,000, and are categorized by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as Least Concern.

Narwhals have been harvested for hundreds of years by Inuit people in northern Canada and Greenland for meat and ivory, and a regulated subsistence hunt continues.

facts.name: "Narwhal" means "corpse whale"
facts.value: Name "narwhal" means "corpse whale". They are named that way because they often swim with their bellies at the surface of water. Also, they can remain motionless in that position for several minutes.

facts.name: Communicate using clicks
facts.value: Narwhals communicate using clicks, squeals and whistles. These high-pitched sounds may induce deafness in humans.

facts.name: Narwhals have only two teeth
facts.value: Narwhals have only two teeth. One of them grows rapidly and passes right through the upper lip, becoming a tusk. Tusk is the most prominent feature of the narwhal's body.

facts.name: Swim in groups called pods
facts.value: Narwhals swim in groups called pods. Pods can be very large, composed of hundreds of animals. More often, pods are smaller, composed of 2 to 10 animals. Often, pods consist of animals of only one sex.

facts.name: Can dive to the depth of 1500 meters
facts.value: Narwhals can dive to the depth of 1500 meters while they are searching for food.

facts.name: Females also develop tusks
facts.value: Females also develop tusks, but their tusks are much shorter than tucks in males.

facts.name: Color of narwhal skin depends on its age
facts.value: Color of narwhal skin depends on its age. At birth, narwhal's skin is bluish-grey. Juvenile animals have bluish-black color of the skin. Adult animals are mottled grey. Very old narwhals are almost entirely white.

facts.name: Baby narwhal is brown at birth
facts.value: Baby narwhal is brown at birth. It is usually 1.5 meters long and can have 80 kilograms of weight.

facts.name: Mating takes place during spring
facts.value: Mating takes place during spring. Males reach sexual maturity between the age 8 and 10. Pregnancy lasts 14 to 15 months and ends with one baby.

facts.name: Tusk is made of ivory
facts.value: Tusk is made of ivory. It is spiral, hollow and can reach the length of up to 2.6 meters.

facts.name: Narwhals are carnivores
facts.value: Narwhals are carnivores (meat-eaters). They feed on fish, shrimps, squids, cods.

facts.name: Narwhals are large animals
facts.value: Narwhals are large animals. Males are larger than females. Males can reach length of 5.5 meters and weigh of 1.6 tones. Females are few feet shorter, usually weighing less than one ton.

facts.name: Close relatives of bottlenose dolphins
facts.value: Narwhals are close relatives of bottlenose dolphins, orcas, belugas and harbour porpoise.

facts.name: Not sure why narwhals develop tusks
facts.value: Scientists are not sure why narwhals develop tusks. They probably use tusks during mating rituals, to attract females, and to gain a chance to mate. Males can broke tusks during the fight. Broken tusk cannot be repaired (it does not re-grow).

facts.name: Survive up to 50 years in the wild
facts.value: Narwhal can survive up to 50 years in the wild.

related.definition: The beluga whale   is an Arctic and sub-Arctic cetacean.
The killer whale or orca  is a toothed whale belonging to the oceanic dolphin family, of which it is the largest member.
A marine mammal of temperate and tropical waters worldwide, having a short protruding beak, a gray or brown stocky body, and a prominent curved dorsal fin.
The harbour porpoise  is one of six species of porpoise.
The blue whale  is a marine mammal belonging to the baleen whale parvorder, Mysticeti.
The common minke whale is a species of minke whale within the suborder of baleen whales.
The short-finned pilot whale is one of the two species of cetaceans in the genus Globicephala, which it shares with the long-finned pilot whale.
The fin whale , also known as finback whale or common rorqual and formerly known as herring whale or razorback whale, is a cetacean belonging to the parvorder of baleen whales.
Cuvier's beaked whale is the most widely distributed of all the beaked whales.
The pygmy right whale  is a member of the cetotheres,  a family of baleen whales, which until 2012 were thought to be extinct.
